definition:
Given a set of samples $X_1,\ldots,X_n$ from a given probability
distribution $f$ with an unknown parameter $\theta\in\Theta$, where
$\Theta$ is the parameter space that is a subset of $\mathbb{R}^m$. Let
$U(=U(X_1,\ldots,X_n))$ be an estimator of $\theta$. Allowing the sample
size $n$ to vary, we get a sequence of estimators for $\theta$:
$$\begin{aligned}
U_1 &=& U(X_1),\\
&\vdots& \\
U_n &=& U(X_1,\ldots,X_n), \\
&\vdots&\end{aligned}$$ We say that the sequence of estimators
$\lbrace U_n \rbrace$ *consistent* (or that $U$ is a *consistent
estimator* of $\theta$), if $U_i$ converges in probability to $\theta$
for *every* $\theta\in\Theta$. That is, for every $\varepsilon>0$,
$$\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}P(|h_n-\theta|\geq\varepsilon)=0$$ for all
$\theta\in\Theta$.\
\
**Remark**. Suppose $U$ is an estimator of $\theta$ such that the
sequence $\lbrace U_n\rbrace$ is consistent. If
$\alpha_n\to\alpha\in\mathbb{R}$ and $\beta_n\to\beta\in
\mathbb{R}^m$ are two convergent sequences of constants with
$0<|\alpha|<\infty$ and $|\beta|<\infty$, then the sequence $\lbrace
V_n\rbrace$, defined by $V_n:=\alpha_n U_n+\beta_n$, is consistent, $V$
is an estimator of $\alpha\theta + \beta$.

First, observe that $$\begin{aligned}
|V_n-(\alpha\theta+\beta)| &=&
|\alpha_nU_n+\beta_n-\alpha\theta-\beta|\\
&\le&|\alpha_nU_n-\alpha\theta|+|\beta_n-\beta|\\
&=&|\alpha_nU_n-\alpha_n\theta+\alpha_n\theta-\alpha\theta|+|\beta_n-\beta|\\
&\le&|\alpha_nU_n-\alpha_n\theta|+|\alpha_n\theta-\alpha\theta|+|\beta_n-\beta|\\
&=&|\alpha_n||U_n-\theta|+|\alpha_n-\alpha||\theta|+|\beta_n-\beta|.\end{aligned}$$
This implies $$\begin{aligned}
&& P(|V_n-(\alpha\theta+\beta)|\ge\varepsilon)
\\&\le& P(|\alpha_n||U_n-\theta|+|\alpha_n-\alpha|
|\theta|+|\beta_n-\beta|\ge\varepsilon)
\\&=&P(|U_n-\theta|\ge
\frac{\varepsilon-|\beta_n-\beta|-|\alpha_n-\alpha||\theta|}{|\alpha_n|}).\end{aligned}$$
As $n\to\infty$, $|\beta_n-\beta|\to 0$,
$|\alpha_n-\alpha||\theta|\to 0$, and $|\alpha_n|\to|\alpha|\ne 0$. So
the last expression goes to $0$ as $n\to\infty$. Therefore,
$$\lim_{n\to\infty}P(|V_n-(\alpha\theta+\beta)|\ge\varepsilon)=0,$$ and
thus $\lbrace V_n\rbrace$ is a consistent sequence of estimators of
$\alpha\theta+\beta$.
